Derek James wrote:

>--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
>  
>
>>The write-up for my phased searching experiments (including some nice 
>>graphs) can be found at:
>>
>>http://www.cgreen.dsl.pipex.com/phasedsearch.htm
>>    
>>
>
>Hey Colin,
>
>I've just now gotten around to reading this write-up thoroughly, and I
>thought I'd comment.
>
>In the section describing Blended Searching you say:
>
>"Subtractive mutations help keep the complexity of a population down,
>however, in a blended search experiment described later the downward
>pressure on complexity exerted by subtractive mutations was found to
>be very light."
>
>This is strange.  Your mutation rates were:
>
>add neuron: 0.001
>add connection: 0.01
>remove neuron: 0.003
>remove connection: 0.03
>
>Is this correct?  Your remove topology mutation rates were triple your
>additive ones?  Are you sure everything is working correctly?  If so,
>how do you account for the fact that your blended run complexity
>increased at nearly the same rate as the complexifying runs?  This
>doesn't seem right.
>  
>
Yes the parameters are all correct and I agree that it seems counter 
intuitive. Actually I think you answered this question yourself in your 
response to John -  crossover. The crossover rate was set to 0.5, so 
structures are continuously propagating through the population. 
Subtractive mutations are only on individual [offspring] genomes, so 
there is a very high probability that the deleted gene will exist in 
numerous other genomes in the population and will persist despite 
subtractive mutations occuring. In fact the propagation of genes through 
crossover is so numerous that the subtractive mutations have hardly any 
effect at all - as demonstrated in the graphs.

As a side note I was just reading a short article in this month's 
Scientific American that briefly discusses the possibility that 
crossover, despite being being good at trying out combinations of genes, 
actually acts as an error correcting technique - that is, if one of the 
parents has a mutated gene that is poor, the other parent is likely to 
have a good copy, and therefore some of the offspring will have a 
complete set of good genes despite having a parent with a mutation. 
Well, it's sort of relevant :)

>Also, it seems very strange to me that the fitness of the evolving
>populations in both complexifying and blended NEAT *decrease* over the
>run.  You speculate that this has to do with speciation culling, I
>believe, but there is either something very wrong with the algorithm
>as implemented or something extremely peculiar about your domain if
>NEAT is evolving progressively *worse* individuals.
>  
>
I truly beleive that this is down to species culling, and the phased 
search graph backs up the idea. SharpNEAT employs elitism at the species 
level, that is, each species' keeps at least it's 1 best genome and in 
the experiments actually kept the best 20%,. Note that if 20% works out 
at less than one then at least one is kept. This means that the only way 
that the best genome's fitness can fall is either by killing off a 
species or because of a bug in the code. Having done a lot of testing 
and experimentation recently I'm fairly confident that this isn't down 
to a bug.

I think it makes sense. If a species is good but has not improved for a 
number of generations (200 in the experiments) then it is culled. Now, 
when an experiment reaches a fitness plateau this is precisely what 
happens with each good species in turn. They are then replaced with less 
fit species and how fit those species are can vary. e.g. in the OCR 
experiment the populaiton size was quite small (150), so that as the 
geomes become more complex, the dynamic speciation threshold must 
increase in order to keep the number of species at a given level. This 
means that genome that were previously in different species will now be 
in the same species. Now consider that all of the fit species where 
probably spawned from each other and are therefore probably quite 
similar, as we now increase the speciation threshold, they slowly merge 
back into a single species, leaving the rest of the populatin to be made 
up of poor species... these are what gets left behind when species are 
culled.

Probably all of that needs explaining in more detail and needs more 
experimentation to back it up, but I do feel that this is what's really 
happening. And the theory is partly backed up by the fact that the 
phased search had a population of far less complex genomes and didn't 
suffer from a drop in fitness.

Have a look back in the archives, I think species culling was discussed 
some time ago when I poitned out that quite often a jump in fitness can 
be seen shortly after culling the fittest species. This is because the 
species, although good, is actually stuck in a local optimum, by killing 
it we give the other species a better chance at finding a solution.

Colin.
